author: Shawn Langlois
title: Ford Mustang, America’s favorite first car
text:
The year was 1986, and I’d just scored my first car — a proud whale of a ride that comfortably fit six with a trunk big enough to sneak a few friends into the drive-in. Top it off with a sound system blasting Duran Duran and only the slightest mothball whiff of the grandmother who drove it before me.
Ah, yes — the Oldsmobile.
The chicks didn’t really dig it, but I sure did.
If Instagram had been around back then, I probably would have posted some epic shots of me leaning on the hood with hashtags like #SwagWagon and #TheLoveSedan. That’s the kind of thing kids are doing these days as social media has given them a platform to profess their automotive love.
Don’t miss: The millennial generation is not into cars — or cable
Sadly, Oldsmobile doesn't rate with the new generation (in fact, GM dropped the Oldsmobile marque more than 10 years ago). Nor does my second car: the Buick LeSabre. These old classics get no Insta love. Instead, a redesigned classic seems to have emerged as the favorite first car among today’s connected youth: the Ford Mustang.
A red Ford Mustang, to be exact.
That’s the conclusion reached by an AutoNation AN, -0.21% survey, which looked at 173,292 Instagram posts to determine the cars that young Americans choose as their first. Ford’s F, -2.35% high ranking is reflected in its latest monthly results, which showed Mustang sales up 70% from a year ago — its best August performance since way back in 2007.
All told, the Honda HMC, -2.49% brand, led by the Civic and the Accord, scored higher than Ford, but Ford’s muscle car was the top model. The Volkswagen Beetle and Jetta rounded out the top five.
